item.title: [SOLR-15965] PKIAuthenticationPlugin uses encryption instead of signatures
item.description:
Our PKIAuthenticationPlugin uses a very weak cipher when sending SolrAuth header information. There are several factors involved here:

  • The Java cipher suite represented by RSA/ECB/NoPadding is completely deterministic.
  • The only way to rotate a server's public key is via restart because we have no way to reload the PublicKeyHandler.

An older example of why ECB is a poor choice for data integrity is the ECB Penguin

A mitigation to the associated risk here is that all transport should already be occurring over a secure channel (i.e. HTTPS), so the risk of a man-in-the-middle attack is low. However, there are other concerns.

RSA/ECB/NoPadding does not include a MAC, so is susceptible to false parsing. If the encryption key has rotated then we are susceptible to issues like SOLR-15961

Further, in cases where the parsing fails, we can end up logging the plaintext and cipher text of the authentication header. Even without the plaintext, and having only the cipher text, it would not be too challenging for an attacker to extract a key given that they know the format of the header to be SolrAuth <nodeName> base64(enc(<user> <timestamp>)) and user is often the literal $ string and timestamp is a recent long in millis.

There are other, better, more modern cipher algorithms that can be used, and I am still researching which ones would work for us, what key initialization would look like, etc. Additionally, changing this on upgrade would not permit a rolling restart. At a minimum, we would need a "bridge" 8.11.2 release so that users can upgrade from 8.x -> 8.11.2 -> 9.0. In this scenario, we would need the following behavior:

  encryption decryption
8.x RSA/ECB/NoPadding RSA/ECB/NoPadding
8.11.2 RSA/ECB/NoPadding RSA/ECB/NoPadding
OR New Alg
9.x New Alg New Alg

Alternative options are to discard rolling restart capability going from 8->9, ask users to disable PKI Authentication for their clusters, or require users to bridge via 9.0 before upgrading to further 9.x releases. None of those alternatives sound palatable to me, but the community may disagree.

comments.comment:
Just read through rather quickly, and this seems like something that would be good idea to fix.

The bridge release does feel like the most reasonable approach for users, as long as we are able to do this before 9x i.e. 9.0 is released with support for only the new algorithm.

Also, it might make sense to add a warning or something in places where we log plaintext and cipher text so that the users know better than to have logging configured to debug mode (specially for this particular class).

At a minimum, we would need a "bridge" 8.11.2 release so that users can upgrade from 8.x -> 8.11.2 -> 9.0. In this scenario, we would need the following behavior:

I think this is fine, but couldn't we have backward compatibility via configuration? Maybe send the algorithm as a new header, and let the new code select the algorithm of outgoing request via system properties (default to the new/more secure algorithms)? Users could:

  • Have all nodes keep using current RSA/ECB/NoPadding for outgoing requests (but now send the algorithm used as a header).
  • Have receiving nodes use algorithm specified in the new header, but default to RSA/ECB/NoPadding when the new header is not set
  • Upgrade all nodes in the cluster to 9.x (or whatever version this is released with)
  • Change algos to something more secure (or remove the override done via system property to allow the new default take place) and restart the cluster again.

I'll take two full cluster restarts, but will make this possible. Regardless, we may want this in 8.11.x too.

I think that’s doable… We would need two configuration properties, one for which algorithm to use when encoding and one to check if we are allowed to use the old algorithm for decoding.

Not sure if we need to send the version information as a new header or could embed that in the same header. No version information materially maps to v1 or old algorithm.

I think this is fine, but couldn't we have backward compatibility via configuration? Maybe send the algorithm as a new header, and let the new code select the algorithm of outgoing request via system properties (default to the new/more secure algorithms)?

Was thinking about this more, I think we can bundle them into a single setting. Maybe something like solr.pki.allowWeakCipher or s.p.allowCipherV1 and if that setting is enabled then the node will both send v1 but accept v1 and v2, and if it is false then the node will send v2 and only accept v2.

The reason I wanted a bridge release is because if we go the configuration route we'd have to keep code in place for all of 9.x otherwise. Or designate 9.0 an intermediate upgrade point before users can rolling restart to 9.x if we actually remove the code?

We could also take the opportunity to redo the format instead of being user str(timestamp) we could do two bytes for the timestamp and parse it that way, since it's never passed raw anyway... it's always encrypted and base64'd before it hits the wire.
The property could also be solr.pki.allowedCiphers={v1,v2,v3...} and then operators can specify a list for future cipher algorithm improvements.
Changing security level private to public since based on discussions with trusted experts we think this is probably just an improvement instead of a major problem.
Shouldn't this be a 9.0 blocker?

Trying to grasp the instructions in https://github.com/apache/solr/commit/16760a7#diff-469f7b0e2e6843ecf2eb42ca9e5b867386fe140a061f0043af6838b7853414ebR61-R65 but the bullet list is structured in a strange way, so there is three level-1 bullets and two sub-bullets under the "Either" bullet.

Perhaps you can clarify those steps?

Also, it feels strange to ask people to upgrade to an unlreleased 8.11.2 version. Should we release 8.11.2 first? Perhaps it is cleaner to only discuss the alternative which works from 8.11.1. Then in 9.1 we can add the other (simpler?) alternative involving 8.11.2.

> Should we release 8.11.2 first? 

This might be helpful, but not required. I can volunteer to RM 8.11.2 after this change is merged in, will send out an emailI suppose. That would potentially delay 9.0 by about two weeks if you were planning on starting the vote soon.

> Perhaps you can clarify those steps?

I've been struggling a little bit on how to explain the process. Maybe it would be simpler for users (but more complex for us) if 9.0.z defaulted to acceptVersions=v1,v2 like 8.11.2 is proposed to do. Then the upgrade path would become:

8.x -> 8.11.2 -> 9.0 -> 9.y

If they want to go straight from 8.x to 9.0 or from 8.11.2 to some later 9.y release, then they can do the dance with system properties specifying compatible send/accept versions. I'd rewrite the documentation to call out what the defaults for each version are, and tell users that they need to ensure that the send version and accept version match for whatever rolling upgrade permutation they are doing, but leave them to figure out the specifics themselves.

I'd prefer to release 9.0 first. Perhaps we can put in the 8.x -> 9.0 description as the default one, and add an additional paragraph explaining that "...once 8.11.2 is available, there will be an alternative upgrade path without the property dance". Then early adopters can upgrade early, while those who wait yet another few weeks will have a simpler path.

Would be cool if we had a tool e.g. bin/solr upgradehelp --from <from-version|solr-url>, which would print out recommended steps, as this is a bit complex, both lucene-index compatibility and issues like this. Often, for major upgrades that tool might say "install a brand new cluster and re-index", but other times be smarter? It could also validate the old solrconfig/schema and print warnings for unsupported stuff.

Even if we release 9.0, if we're planning to release 8.11.2 then should we not mentioned that path in the 9.0 upgrade docs? Or do we have the ability to go back and edit them easily now that Antora is publishing all of the versions (houston do you know?)

I agree that having multiple upgrade paths outlined is probably more confusing than helpful. You can see from my conversation on the PR with Tomas that it's something that went through a few iterations.

What about:

SOLR-15965: Internode communication secured by PKI Authentication has changed formats. For detailed information, see PKI Authentication Plugin.

A rolling upgrade from Solr 8 to Solr 9 requires the following multiple restart sequence:
1. Upgrade to Solr 9 and set system properties: solr.pki.sendVersion=v1 and solr.pki.acceptVersions=v1,v2. This will allow Solr 9 nodes to send messages to Solr 8 nodes while the upgrade is in progress.
2. Restart with solr.pki.sendVersion=v2 (default, can be unset) and solr.pki.acceptVersions=v1,v2. This will force all nodes to send the new header.
3. (Optional) Restart with system property solr.pki.acceptVersions=v2 (default, can be unset) to prevent outdated nodes from connecting to your cluster.

Replacing the bulleted list with a numbered list, providing a little bit more rationale. After 8.11.2 is released, we can add a line like "When upgrading from 8.11.2 or newer, you can optionally skip step #1)

 

> Would be cool if we had a tool e.g. bin/solr upgradehelp --from <from-version|solr-url>

In a separate issue, please

The current way we are thinking about it, the 9.0 ref guide will be basically the nightly build of branch_9_0, so whatever fixes you push will be propagated to the real ref-guide, before the 9.0.1 release is made.
